answer: The Commonwealth Bank of Australia (CBA) is a major Australian bank founded in 1911, offering retail, business, and institutional banking services globally. It is headquartered in Sydney and is the largest bank in Australia by assets and market capitalization. CBA provides a wide range of financial services including banking, insurance, and investment.

results.title: Commonwealth Bank - Wikipedia
results.content:
The Commonwealth Bank of Australia (CBA), also known as Commonwealth Bank or simply CommBank, is an Australian multinationalbank with businesses across New Zealand, Asia, the United States, and the United Kingdom. It provides a variety of financial services, including retail, business and institutional banking, funds management, superannuation, insurance, investment, and broking services. The Commonwealth Bank is the largest Australian listed company on the Australian Securities Exchange as of [...] 3.   ^"Credit ratings". _commbank.com.au_. Standard & Poor's. Archived from the original on 5 October 2024. Retrieved 5 October 2024.
4.   ^"ASX 50 List / Market Capitalisation Accurate on: 28 July 2024". _ASX 50_. Australian Securities Exchange. 28 July 2024. Retrieved 28 July 2024.
5.   ^"How much were CBA shares when they first floated?". 25 March 2022.
6.   ^"Commonwealth Bank Corporate Office". _Corporate Office HQ_. 22 January 2021. Retrieved 15 September 2021. [...] In May 2015, a report by Market Forces showed that CBA is the single biggest lender to fossil fuel projects within the Great Barrier Reef World Heritage Area during the six-year period from 2008 to 2014.( Almost immediately following, protests were held at over fifty CBA branches in Australia and around the world.( Billboards, hoardings and branch signs were revised to read "Coal Bank" and company slogans changed to highlight its investment in fossil fuels.(

The **Commonwealth Bank of Australia** (**CBA**), also known as **Commonwealth Bank** or simply **CommBank**, is an Australian [multinational](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Multinational_corporation "Multinational corporation")[bank](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bank "Bank") with businesses across [New Zealand](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/New_Zealand "New Zealand"), [Asia](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Asia "Asia"), the [United States](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States "United States"), and the [United Kingdom](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_Kingdom "United Kingdom"). It provides a variety of [financial services](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Financial_service "Financial service"), including retail, business and institutional banking, [funds management](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Funds_management "Funds management"), [superannuation](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Superannuation "Superannuation"), insurance, investment, and broking services. The Commonwealth Bank is the largest Australian listed company on the [Australian Securities Exchange](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Australian_Securities_Exchange "Australian Securities Exchange") as of July 2024, with brands including [Bankwest](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bankwest "Bankwest"), Colonial First State Investments, [ASB Bank](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/ASB_Bank "ASB Bank") (New Zealand), [Commonwealth Securities](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Commonwealth_Securities "Commonwealth Securities") (CommSec) and Commonwealth Insurance (CommInsure).[[4]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Commonwealth_Bank#cite_note-4) Its former constituent parts were the **Commonwealth Trading Bank of Australia**, the **Commonwealth Savings Bank of Australia**, and the **Commonwealth Development Bank**.

Founded in 1911 by the [Australian Government](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Australian_Government "Australian Government") and fully privatised in 1996, the Commonwealth Bank is one of the [big four](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Big_Four_(banking)#Australia "Big Four (banking)") Australian banks, with the [National Australia Bank](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/National_Australia_Bank "National Australia Bank") (NAB), [ANZ](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Australia_and_New_Zealand_Banking_Group "Australia and New Zealand Banking Group") and [Westpac](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Westpac "Westpac"). The bank was listed on the Australian Stock Exchange on 12 Sep 1991.[[5]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Commonwealth_Bank#cite_note-5)

The former global headquarters of Commonwealth Bank were the [Commonwealth Trading Bank Building](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Commonwealth_Trading_Bank_Building "Commonwealth Trading Bank Building") on the corner of [Pitt Street](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pitt_Street "Pitt Street") and [Martin Place](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Martin_Place "Martin Place"), [Sydney](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sydney "Sydney"), which was refurbished from 2012 for retail and commercial uses, and (from 1984 to 2012) the [State Savings Bank Building](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/State_Savings_Bank_Building "State Savings Bank Building") on [Martin Place](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Martin_Place "Martin Place"), which was sold in 2012 to [Macquarie Bank](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Macquarie_Bank "Macquarie Bank"). The headquarters were then moved, splitting between two locations; Tower 1 of 201 Sussex Street and the Commonwealth Bank Place; a new complex of two nine-storey buildings in [Darling Harbour](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Darling_Harbour "Darling Harbour") on the western side of Sydney's city centre.[[6]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Commonwealth_Bank#cite_note-6) In 2022, the headquarters were consolidated into the Commonwealth Bank Place, with Tower 1 of 201 Sussex Street remaining as a secondary head office.[[7]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Commonwealth_Bank#cite_note-7)

In 2018, findings from the [Royal Commission into Misconduct in the Banking, Superannuation and Financial Services Industry](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Royal_Commission_into_Misconduct_in_the_Banking,_Superannuation_and_Financial_Services_Industry "Royal Commission into Misconduct in the Banking, Superannuation and Financial Services Industry") have indicated a negative culture within the bank, amid allegations of fraud, deception, and money laundering, among various other crimes.[[8]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Commonwealth_Bank#cite_note-8)

In 2022, the Commonwealth Bank held the 49th position in the "Top 1000 World Banks".[[9]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Commonwealth_Bank#cite_note-9) As of August 2024 it is listed as the 66th largest company in the world by market cap.

History
-------

[[edit](https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Commonwealth_Bank&action=edit&section=1 "Edit section: History")]

### Foundation (1911–1919)

[[edit](https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Commonwealth_Bank&action=edit&section=2 "Edit section: Foundation (1911–1919)")]

See also: [Reserve Bank of Australia](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Reserve_Bank_of_Australia "Reserve Bank of Australia")

The Commonwealth Bank of Australia was established by the _Commonwealth Bank Act 1911_, introduced by the [Andrew Fisher](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Andrew_Fisher "Andrew Fisher")[Labor](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Australian_Labor_Party "Australian Labor Party") government, which favoured bank [nationalisation](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Nationalisation "Nationalisation"), with effect on 22 December 1911.[[10]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Commonwealth_Bank#cite_note-CN_MP-TDMP2-R-02-10)[[11]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Commonwealth_Bank#cite_note-CN_MP-TDMP2-R-03-11) In a rare move for the time, the bank was to have both savings and general bank business. The bank was also the first bank in Australia to receive a federal government guarantee. The bank's earliest and most strenuous proponent was the flamboyant American-Australian Labor politician [King O'Malley](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/King_O%27Malley "King O'Malley"), and its first governor was Sir [Denison Miller](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Denison_Miller "Denison Miller").

The bank opened its first branch in [Melbourne](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Melbourne "Melbourne") on 15 July 1912.[[12]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Commonwealth_Bank#cite_note-12) In an agreement with [Australia Post](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Australia_Post "Australia Post") that exists to this day, the bank also traded through post office agencies. In 1912, it took over the [State Savings Bank of Tasmania](https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=State_Savings_Bank_of_Tasmania&action=edit&redlink=1 "State Savings Bank of Tasmania (page does not exist)"), and by 1913 it had branches in all six states.

In 1916, the bank moved its head office to [Sydney](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sydney "Sydney"). It also followed the Australian army into [New Guinea](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/New_Guinea "New Guinea"), where it opened a branch in [Rabaul](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Rabaul "Rabaul") and agencies elsewhere.

### Central bank (1920–1959)

[[edit](https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Commonwealth_Bank&action=edit&section=3 "Edit section: Central bank (1920–1959)")]

[![Image 7](https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/22/CBA_Martin_Place_001.jpg/250px-CBA_Martin_Place_001.jpg)](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/File:CBA_Martin_Place_001.jpg)

The [Commonwealth Trading Bank Building](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Commonwealth_Trading_Bank_Building "Commonwealth Trading Bank Building") (1916-1960)

In 1920, the bank began acquiring [central bank](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Central_bank "Central bank") powers when it took over the responsibility for the issue of Australian bank notes from the Department of the Treasury.[[13]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Commonwealth_Bank#cite_note-13) Also in 1920, the Commonwealth Bank took over the [Queensland Government Savings Bank](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Queensland_Government_Savings_Bank "Queensland Government Savings Bank").

In 1924, the federal government of [Stanley Bruce](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Stanley_Bruce "Stanley Bruce") sought to place further checks and limits on the powers of the governor of the bank, and passed the _Commonwealth Bank Act, 1924_, which created a seven-member Board of Directors comprising the governor, the Secretary of the Treasury, and six directors "actively engaged in agriculture, commerce, finance or industry", and a Chairman of the Board elected annual from its members.[[14]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Commonwealth_Bank#cite_note-14) The first six board members were appointed on 10 October 1924: [Sir John Garvan](https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=John_Garvan&action=edit&redlink=1 "John Garvan (page does not exist)"), [Sir Robert Gibson](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Robert_Gibson_(businessman) "Robert Gibson (businessman)"), [Sir Samuel Hordern](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Samuel_Hordern "Samuel Hordern"), [Robert McComas](https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Robert_McComas&action=edit&redlink=1 "Robert McComas (page does not exist)"), Richard Samuel Drummond, and John McKenzie Lees.[[15]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Commonwealth_Bank#cite_note-board1-15)[[16]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Commonwealth_Bank#cite_note-16) Garvan was appointed as the first chairman on 13 October 1924.[[17]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Commonwealth_Bank#cite_note-garvan-17)

In 1931, the bank board came into conflict with the [Labor](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Australian_Labor_Party "Australian Labor Party") government of [James Scullin](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/James_Scullin "James Scullin"). The bank's chairman Sir Robert Gibson refused to expand credit in response to the [Great Depression](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Great_Depression "Great Depression"), as had been proposed by Treasurer [Edward Theodore](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ted_Theodore "Ted Theodore") unless the government cut pensions, which Scullin refused to do. The conflict surrounding this issue led to the fall of the government, and to demands from Labor for reform of the bank and more direct government control over monetary policy.

Also in 1931, it took over the savings bank business of the [Government Savings Bank of New South Wales](https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Government_Savings_Bank_of_New_South_Wales&action=edit&redlink=1 "Government Savings Bank of New South Wales (page does not exist)") (est. 1871), the current account and fixed deposit business of the NSW Rural Bank Department, and the State Savings Bank of Western Australia (est. 1863).

In 1942, the Commonwealth Banking Corporation (CBC) suspended its operations in [Papua New Guinea](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Papua_New_Guinea "Papua New Guinea") as the [Imperial Japanese Army](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Imperial_Japanese_Army "Imperial Japanese Army") captured many of the towns in which it operated, and bombed [Port Moresby](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Port_Moresby "Port Moresby"). The bank resumed operations later, possibly in 1944.

The bank had many branches across Papua New Guinea including Port Moresby, Boroko, Rabaul, Lae, Wau, Bulolo, Goroka, Kavieng, Madang, Mount Hagen, Kundiawa, Popondetta, and Wewak. On Bougainville, there was Kieta, Panguna, Arawa and early on a part-time sub-branch at Loloho. It maintained those facilities to support trade, local business, government, and small savers.

The Commonwealth Bank received almost all central bank powers in emergency legislation passed during [World War II](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/World_War_II "World War II") and at the end of the war, it used this power to begin a dramatic expansion of the economy. This was also the aim of the federal government at the time, which attempted to compel the Australian states to conduct their banking with the Commonwealth under the _Banking Act 1945_ (Cth), but the High Court in _Melbourne Corporation v Commonwealth_ (1947) 74 CLR 31, blocked this move.

In August 1945, the federal government of [Ben Chifley](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ben_Chifley "Ben Chifley") passed the _Commonwealth Bank Act, 1945_, which repealed the 1925 act and abolished the Board of Directors, returning full executive control of the bank to the governor.[[18]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Commonwealth_Bank#cite_note-18)

The government also dramatically expanded immigration programs. In response, the bank established a Migrant Information Service (later known as the Australian Financial & Migrant Information Service, or AFMIS). The bank expanded during this period, and in just five years it opened hundreds of branches throughout Australia and in 1951 it established a branch in the [Solomon Islands](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Solomon_Islands "Solomon Islands").

In 1958 and 1959, there was a controversy concerning the dual functions of the organization, operating as the central bank on the one hand and a commercial bank on the other. As a result, the government separated the two roles, creating the [Reserve Bank of Australia](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Reserve_Bank_of_Australia "Reserve Bank of Australia") to exercise the central bank function, and leaving the Commonwealth Banking Corporation to operate purely as a commercial bank. Those commercial functions were exercised by the organization's constituent sections: the Commonwealth Trading Bank of Australia, the Commonwealth Savings Bank of Australia, and the newly formed Commonwealth Development Bank.

From 1958 to 1976 the Commonwealth Bank operated savings bank agencies in the [New Hebrides](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/New_Hebrides "New Hebrides").

### Diversification (1960–1991)

[[edit](https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Commonwealth_Bank&action=edit&section=4 "Edit section: Diversification (1960–1991)")]

[![Image 8](https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/6/66/Commonwealth_Bank_old_logo.jpg)](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/File:Commonwealth_Bank_old_logo.jpg)

1980s logo

A new Commonwealth Development Bank was established in 1960 and during the 1970s the bank diversified its business into areas like insurance and travel. It established a finance company, CBFC in 1974. The bank also became more heavily involved in foreign currency trading and international banking in general.

The bank actively supported the introduction of [decimal currency](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Decimal_currency "Decimal currency") in the years leading up to 1966 and, like most banks, it gradually converted its paper records onto a new computer-based system. The bank created the first [credit card](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Credit_card "Credit card") in Australia in 1974 when it established [Bankcard](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bankcard "Bankcard"). In later years the bank began offering [MasterCard](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/MasterCard "MasterCard") (1984) and [Visa](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Visa_(credit_card) "Visa (credit card)") (1993) cards as well.

In 1974, as [Papua New Guinea](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Papua_New_Guinea "Papua New Guinea") approached independence, the bank formally handed over its PNG operations to the newly created and government-owned [Papua New Guinea Banking Corporation](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bank_South_Pacific "Bank South Pacific") (PNGBC). The bank retained a restricted branch in Port Moresby that it finally closed in 1982.

In 1981 the bank transferred its operations in the [Solomon Islands](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Solomon_Islands "Solomon Islands") to the [National Bank of Solomon Islands](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/National_Bank_of_Solomon_Islands "National Bank of Solomon Islands"), which operated as a joint venture (51% Commonwealth Bank, 49% Government of the Solomon Islands).

In 1989 the bank acquired 75 per cent of [ASB Bank](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/ASB_Bank "ASB Bank") in [New Zealand](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/New_Zealand "New Zealand").

In 1991 the bank acquired the failing Victorian Government-owned [State Bank of Victoria](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/State_Bank_of_Victoria "State Bank of Victoria") (est. 1842).[[19]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Commonwealth_Bank#cite_note-19)

### Privatisation (1991–present)

[[edit](https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Commonwealth_Bank&action=edit&section=5 "Edit section: Privatisation (1991–present)")]

[![Image 9](https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/9/93/Commonwealth_Bank.svg/250px-Commonwealth_Bank.svg.png)](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/File:Commonwealth_Bank.svg)

Logo used until 2020

[![Image 10](https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/15/%281%29Commonwealth_Bank_Sydney.jpg/250px-%281%29Commonwealth_Bank_Sydney.jpg)](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/File:(1)Commonwealth_Bank_Sydney.jpg)

48 [Martin Place](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Martin_Place "Martin Place"); the Commonwealth Bank's headquarters from 1990-2009[[20]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Commonwealth_Bank#cite_note-:0-20)

Between 1991 and 1996 the Australian Government under the [Keating government](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Keating_government "Keating government") fully privatised the Commonwealth Bank. The first share offer in 1991 was valued at $1,292 million, the second in 1993 for $1,700 million and the third was sold for $5,000 million in 1996.[[21]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Commonwealth_Bank#cite_note-21) It is a public company, but one of the few such companies in Australia whose official name does not end in 'Limited'.

In 1994 Commonwealth sold its shares in [National Bank of Solomon Islands](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/National_Bank_of_Solomon_Islands "National Bank of Solomon Islands") to [Bank of Hawaii](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bank_of_Hawaii "Bank of Hawaii"). In 1994, Commonwealth took a 50% share in PT Bank International Indonesia.

On 10 March 2000, the Commonwealth Bank and Colonial Limited announced their intention to merge, with seven Commonwealth Bank shares being offered for twenty Colonial Shares. The merger received final approval from the Supreme Court of Victoria on 31 May 2000 and was completed on 13 June 2000. This brought into the fold Colonial’s stake in [Colonial National Bank](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Colonial_National_Bank "Colonial National Bank"), the former National Bank of Fiji. The bank also acquired the remaining 25% of [ASB Bank](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/ASB_Bank "ASB Bank").

Asian banking opportunities in 2000, saw the bank acquire full ownership of PT Bank International Indonesia and rename it (PT Bank Commonwealth). This bank now has over 16 branches and has opened several FX shops to cater to Commonwealth Bank clients who are tourists in [Bali](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bali "Bali").

In 2005, the bank established strategic co-operation agreements with two Chinese banks, Jinan City Commercial Bank and [Hangzhou City Commercial Bank](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hangzhou_City_Commercial_Bank "Hangzhou City Commercial Bank"); it took an 11% stake in Jinan Commercial, and a 19.9% stake in Hangzhou Commercial. Commonwealth also established a representative office in [Bangalore](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bangalore "Bangalore"), [India](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/India "India").

On 27 January 2006, the bank acquired the remaining 49% stake in Colonial National Bank (Fiji).

[![Image 11](https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/9e/CeBIT_Signage_and_Flags-1460_%28cropped%29.jpg/250px-CeBIT_Signage_and_Flags-1460_%28cropped%29.jpg)](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/File:CeBIT_Signage_and_Flags-1460_(cropped).jpg)

Tower 1, 201 Sussex Street; headquarters from 2010-2022 and now a secondary head office[[20]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Commonwealth_Bank#cite_note-:0-20)

At the beginning of 2008, Commonwealth Bank opened a branch in [Ho Chi Minh City](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ho_Chi_Minh_City "Ho Chi Minh City") (Saigon). Then in October, Commonwealth announced that it had purchased [Bankwest](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bankwest "Bankwest") and St Andrew's Insurances from their parent company [HBOS](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/HBOS "HBOS") for [A$](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Australian_dollar "Australian dollar")2.1 billion.[[22]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Commonwealth_Bank#cite_note-22)[[23]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Commonwealth_Bank#cite_note-23) The acquisition was scheduled to be completed in early 2009, subject to regulatory approval. Lastly, on 24 December, Commonwealth announced that it had, in joint [partnership](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Partnership "Partnership") with [Aussie Home Loans](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Aussie_Home_Loans "Aussie Home Loans"), purchased [Wizard Home Loans](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Wizard_Home_Loans "Wizard Home Loans").[[24]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Commonwealth_Bank#cite_note-24) As part of the deal, the Commonwealth Bank will acquire Wizard mortgages up to the value of [A$](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Australian_dollar "Australian dollar")4 billion. Commonwealth Bank held about 30 percent of the loan business of financial advisory company [Storm Financial](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Storm_Financial "Storm Financial") when it collapsed in January 2009.[[25]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Commonwealth_Bank#cite_note-Osborne1-25)

In December 2009, Commonwealth sold [Colonial National Bank](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Colonial_National_Bank "Colonial National Bank") to [Bank of South Pacific](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bank_of_South_Pacific "Bank of South Pacific").

The bank transferred its [ATM](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Automated_teller_machine "Automated teller machine") service desk from [HP Enterprise Services](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/HP_Enterprise_Services "HP Enterprise Services") in [Adelaide](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Adelaide "Adelaide") to ITS ([Armaguard](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Armaguard "Armaguard")) in [Sydney](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sydney "Sydney") in March 2012. The bank will change from [NCR](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/NCR_Corporation "NCR Corporation") and [Diebold](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Diebold "Diebold") ATMs to [Wincor Nixdorf](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Wincor_Nixdorf "Wincor Nixdorf") ATMs over the coming years.

The bank is the only financial services organisation to appear in the Dream Employers' top 20 list of preferred employers for 2010 and 2011.[[26]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Commonwealth_Bank#cite_note-26)

During the [Royal Commission into Misconduct in the Banking, Superannuation and Financial Services Industry](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Royal_Commission_into_Misconduct_in_the_Banking,_Superannuation_and_Financial_Services_Industry "Royal Commission into Misconduct in the Banking, Superannuation and Financial Services Industry") it was discovered that the Commonwealth Bank had charged dead people for financial advice services.[[27]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Commonwealth_Bank#cite_note-27) On 9 May 2018, Commonwealth Bank settled an interest rate rigging case brought by [ASIC](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Australian_Securities_and_Investments_Commission "Australian Securities and Investments Commission") for $25 million. In the settlement, the bank admitted it engaged in "unconscionable conduct" and manipulated the bank bill swap rate five times between February and June 2012.[[28]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Commonwealth_Bank#cite_note-28)

On 16 November 2023, the bank announced divestment of PT Bank Commonwealth to [Bank OCBC NISP](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bank_OCBC_NISP "Bank OCBC NISP").[[29]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Commonwealth_Bank#cite_note-29)

Controversies
-------------

[[edit](https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Commonwealth_Bank&action=edit&section=6 "Edit section: Controversies")]

### Environmental

[[edit](https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Commonwealth_Bank&action=edit&section=7 "Edit section: Environmental")]

Commonwealth Bank is one of the major Australian banks known to be financing and profiting from activities destructive to the Great Barrier Reef, something the bank has been facing increased public scrutiny over since a 2013 report by Market Forces;[[30]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Commonwealth_Bank#cite_note-30) the _Sydney Morning Herald_ stated:[[31]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Commonwealth_Bank#cite_note-31)

> _Australia's big four banks are leading lenders to the massive expansion in coal and gas shipments through the Great Barrier Reef, contradicting their own pledges to curb carbon emissions and preserve sensitive environmental areas. ... The CBA, meanwhile, highlighted its achievement to cut carbon emissions from operations by 35,000 tonnes in 2012. A single bulk carrier shipment of coal exported from Australia would result in final emissions of four times those savings._
> 
> 
> 
> — Julien Vincent, campaigner with Market Forces, May 2013.

In 2014, CBA and the big four Australian banks faced increased pressure to end their support for reef-threatening mining projects, as surveys have shown that "the big four banks would be risking customers shifting up to $236 billion in household deposits if they were to finance a project like the Abbot Point expansion".[[32]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Commonwealth_Bank#cite_note-32)

In late 2014, it "was revealed [CBA] was advising Indian coal miner Adani on its proposed development in Queensland's Galilee basin",[[33]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Commonwealth_Bank#cite_note-33) while by 2015, it has been reported that "all the major American and European banks have refused funds to the project, citing environmental damage".[[34]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Commonwealth_Bank#cite_note-34)

In May 2015, a report by Market Forces showed that CBA is the single biggest lender to fossil fuel projects within the Great Barrier Reef World Heritage Area during the six-year period from 2008 to 2014.[[35]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Commonwealth_Bank#cite_note-35) Almost immediately following, protests were held at over fifty CBA branches in Australia and around the world.[[36]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Commonwealth_Bank#cite_note-theguardian.com-36)[[37]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Commonwealth_Bank#cite_note-37) Billboards, hoardings and branch signs were revised to read "Coal Bank" and company slogans changed to highlight its investment in fossil fuels.[[38]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Commonwealth_Bank#cite_note-38)

Later in May, a report by MSCI showed that while other banks are reducing their funding for fossil fuel projects, Australia's largest banks are ramping up this same funding; _[The Guardian](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/The\_Guardian "The Guardian")_ reported:[[36]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Commonwealth_Bank#cite_note-theguardian.com-36)

> _Australia's largest banks have committed about 10% of their known loan arrangements to the financing of risky fossil fuel projects that may become 'stranded' if the world is to avoid disastrous climate change, new research has estimated._
> 
> 
> 
> — _[The Guardian](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/The\_Guardian "The Guardian")_, May 2015.

### 2008 financial planning scandal

[[edit](https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Commonwealth_Bank&action=edit&section=8 "Edit section: 2008 financial planning scandal")]

In October 2008, former CBA financial planner [Jeff Morris](http://www.abc.net.au/news/2018-06-29/jeff-morris.jpg/9921310) alleged to the [Australian Securities and Investments Commission](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Australian_Securities_and_Investments_Commission "Australian Securities and Investments Commission") (ASIC) and subsequently a Senate Inquiry, the extent of the misconduct of CBA's financial planning arm, Commonwealth Financial Planning Limited (CFPL), but it was not until 16 months later that ASIC would launch an investigation.[[39]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Commonwealth_Bank#cite_note-39) "There was forgery and dishonest concealment of material facts," the Senate Inquiry found in its report.[[40]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Commonwealth_Bank#cite_note-40) They concluded a Royal Commission or Judicial Inquiry as it was deemed ASIC lacked the investigative powers required to uncover the full extent of the allegations.[[41]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Commonwealth_Bank#cite_note-41) A week following the Senate Inquiry, CEO Ian Narev publicly apologised while announcing a compensation scheme.[[42]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Commonwealth_Bank#cite_note-42) Former CEO Ralph Norris also conceded that he was aware of problems within CFPL acknowledging the presence of rogue financial planners but rejected the assertion of a conspiracy to cover it up.[[43]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Commonwealth_Bank#cite_note-43) CBA has been criticised in the Senate for appointing Dr. Brendan French, who was the General Manager of Group Customer Relations before, as the head of the Open Advice Review program.[[44]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Commonwealth_Bank#cite_note-44)[[45]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Commonwealth_Bank#cite_note-45) The CBA defended Dr. Brendan French successfully in a defamation lawsuit in 2015;[[46]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Commonwealth_Bank#cite_note-46) the decision was a single judge decision and was not appealed after the defence was withdrawn.[[47]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Commonwealth_Bank#cite_note-47) Criticism has also been leveled at the fact that Dr. Brendan French was formerly a member of the board of directors of the [Financial Ombudsman Service](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Financial_Ombudsman_Service_(Australia) "Financial Ombudsman Service (Australia)") and is now working in CBA with respect to customer complaints.[[48]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Commonwealth_Bank#cite_note-48)

### 2016 $76m Ponzi scheme

[[edit](https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Commonwealth_Bank&action=edit&section=9 "Edit section: 2016 $76m Ponzi scheme")]

In 2016, it was revealed that some CBA staff were implicated in an alleged $76m [Ponzi scheme](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ponzi_scheme "Ponzi scheme") fraud.[[49]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Commonwealth_Bank#cite_note-49) The alleged architects of the scam were professional poker player Bill Jordanou and accountant Robert Zaia.

### Insurance division scandal

[[edit](https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Commonwealth_Bank&action=edit&section=10 "Edit section: Insurance division scandal")]

It was reported alleged systemic issues about the insurance division of CBA. A claimant who suffered a heart attack and nearly died had his claim declined based on an outdated medical definition in his insurance policy.[[50]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Commonwealth_Bank#cite_note-50) The company admitted this decision was a bad judgement.[[51]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Commonwealth_Bank#cite_note-51) The insurer also "refused to pay total permanent disability (TPD) and terminal illness claims on the chance that a dying person facing organ failure may have their life saved by a transplant, and that a person can claim their life insurance if they are declared terminally ill by two doctors and deemed likely to die within 12 months."[[52]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Commonwealth_Bank#cite_note-52) In March 2016, ASIC announced it would be investigating CBA about the allegations.[[53]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Commonwealth_Bank#cite_note-53) After the serious allegations were aired in an episode of _[Four Corners](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Four\_Corners\_(Australian\_TV\_program) "Four Corners (Australian TV program)")_ two parliamentary inquiries were conducted.[[54]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Commonwealth_Bank#cite_note-54) One into the life insurance sector,[[55]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Commonwealth_Bank#cite_note-55) and another into protection of whistleblowers.[[56]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Commonwealth_Bank#cite_note-56) The inquiries found that no staff involved in the wrongdoings were fired. The only person who suffered a consequence was the whistleblower who had tried to do the right thing.[[57]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Commonwealth_Bank#cite_note-57) There were also calls for a [Royal Commission](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Royal_Commission "Royal Commission") into the insurance industry.[[58]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Commonwealth_Bank#cite_note-58) The Financial Services Royal Commission was eventually called and found widespread issues. The Commonwealth Bank was called the gold medallist for ripping off customers by the counsel assisting the royal commissioner.[[59]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Commonwealth_Bank#cite_note-59)

### Money laundering scandal

[[edit](https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Commonwealth_Bank&action=edit&section=11 "Edit section: Money laundering scandal")]

In August 2017, the financial intelligence agency [Australian Transaction Reports and Analysis Centre](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Australian_Transaction_Reports_and_Analysis_Centre "Australian Transaction Reports and Analysis Centre") (AUSTRAC) launched civil proceedings in the [Federal Court of Australia](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Federal_Court_of_Australia "Federal Court of Australia"), alleging that CBA had breached money laundering and terrorism financing laws on 53,700 occasions. The breaches related to the bank's use of intelligent deposit machines (IDMs) between November 2012 and September 2015—the bank claimed that a programming error allowed depositors to instantly credit cash deposits to their accounts, whilst failing to report amounts over $10,000 to AUSTRAC, and not enforcing any limits to the number of transactions.[[60]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Commonwealth_Bank#cite_note-austrac-60)

### Bank bill swap rate allegations

[[edit](https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Commonwealth_Bank&action=edit&section=12 "Edit section: Bank bill swap rate allegations")]

See also: [Libor scandal](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Libor_scandal "Libor scandal") and [Interbank lending market](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Interbank_lending_market "Interbank lending market")

ASIC commenced legal proceedings in the Federal Court on 30 January 2018 alleging manipulation of the [bank bill](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bank_bill "Bank bill") swap rate (BBSW). The BBSW rate is the rate of interest that banks charge to lend money to each other, and is a key interest rate used as the benchmark for interest rates on a number of products, most notably business loans, currency derivatives and floating rate bonds. It is alleged that the manipulations took place on three specific occasions in 2012.[[61]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Commonwealth_Bank#cite_note-61)

### BankWest commercial loan book

[[edit](https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Commonwealth_Bank&action=edit&section=13 "Edit section: BankWest commercial loan book")]

The change from [Basel I](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Basel_I "Basel I") to [Basel II](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Basel_II "Basel II") capitalisation requirements, due to take effect on 1 January 2009, required [BankWest](https://www.bankwest.com.au/) to increase its [Tier 1 capital](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Tier_1_capital "Tier 1 capital") (share capital) by an additional A$17 billion. BankWest's owner HBOS lent this money to Bankwest, but required the money be repaid to meet HBOS's own capital requirements.[[62]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Commonwealth_Bank#cite_note-hearing20151202-62)

HBOS, therefore, agreed to sell BankWest to Commonwealth Bank (CBA) in October 2008. The sale completed on for A$2.1 billion on 19 December 2008, and required Commonwealth Bank to repay the capital HBOS had loaned Bankwest.[[62]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Commonwealth_Bank#cite_note-hearing20151202-62)

One of the provisions of the sale agreement was an ability for CBA to claim a price adjustment. A loan was later found to have been impaired at the time of purchase but had not been identified to Commonwealth Bank by HBOS as impaired during the acquisition.[[62]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Commonwealth_Bank#cite_note-hearing20151202-62)

Commonwealth Bank declared 1,958 out of 26,000 BankWest commercial loans impaired (in default of the loan terms),[[62]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Commonwealth_Bank#cite_note-hearing20151202-62) with a total face value of $17.9 billion. As they were deemed to be in breach of their loan conditions, the bank was able to charge increased interest rates, or require early repayment.[[62]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Commonwealth_Bank#cite_note-hearing20151202-62)

Commonwealth Bank lost A$2 billion on defaulted loans that were not repaid[[62]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Commonwealth_Bank#cite_note-hearing20151202-62) (2.1% of the loan book, in comparison to an average of 0.4% across the [Big Four Australian banks](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Big_Four_(banking)#Australia "Big Four (banking)")).[[62]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Commonwealth_Bank#cite_note-hearing20151202-62) Of the defaulted loans, the calling-in of 117 resulted in the borrowing company going into receivership.[[62]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Commonwealth_Bank#cite_note-hearing20151202-62)

Borrowers complained that they had complied with the monetary conditions of the loans: they had kept up interest payments and repayments, and disputed whether it was reasonable to apply penalty interest and require early repayment for non-monetary issues (for example, not having invested the funds for the purpose borrowed, or no longer having adequate security to back the loan).

The Australian Parliament requested that the Parliament's [Joint Committee on Corporations and Financial Services](https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Joint_Committee_on_Corporations_and_Financial_Services&action=edit&redlink=1 "Joint Committee on Corporations and Financial Services (page does not exist)") conduct an inquiry into the matter,[[63]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Commonwealth_Bank#cite_note-63) which reported on 4 May 2016.

The committee concluded that there was no evidence to suggest that impairment of loans was related to an attempt to 'claw back' any of the BankWest purchase price.[[64]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Commonwealth_Bank#cite_note-bankwestreport-64) However, it did find that "in a minority of cases" there was abuse of the asymmetry of power between the bank and the borrower.[[64]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Commonwealth_Bank#cite_note-bankwestreport-64) The committee recommended that there be improvements in the consistency of lenders' valuation of property used as security for loans.[[64]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Commonwealth_Bank#cite_note-bankwestreport-64)

### Dollarmites

[[edit](https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Commonwealth_Bank&action=edit&section=14 "Edit section: Dollarmites")]

Dollarmites was the Commonwealth Bank's school banking program. In a 2020 Report, the [Australian Securities and Investments Commission](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Australian_Securities_and_Investments_Commission "Australian Securities and Investments Commission") (ASIC) recommended against these programs.[[65]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Commonwealth_Bank#cite_note-65) The [Victorian Government](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Victoria_State_Government "Victoria State Government")[[66]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Commonwealth_Bank#cite_note-66) and later the [Queensland Government](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Queensland_Government "Queensland Government")[[67]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Commonwealth_Bank#cite_note-67) planned to stop allowing these programs in their state schools. Consumer group [Choice](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Choice_(Australian_consumer_organisation) "Choice (Australian consumer organisation)") continued to lobby for more State governments to also ban the banking program from public schools.[[68]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Commonwealth_Bank#cite_note-68) Finally in 2021, after the [New South Wales Government](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Government_of_New_South_Wales "Government of New South Wales") banned it too, the Commonwealth Bank announced the end of the program.[[69]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Commonwealth_Bank#cite_note-69)[[70]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Commonwealth_Bank#cite_note-70)

A subset of Commonwealth Bank staff were found to be fraudulently use the bank’s money, loose change, or their own money to illegitimately activate Youthsaver accounts for financial gain. According to _[The Sydney Morning Herald](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/The\_Sydney\_Morning\_Herald "The Sydney Morning Herald")_, "They would do so when parents had signed up their kids for school banking, often referred to as Dollarmites, but had not deposited money into the account within 30 days. If no deposit had been made, the sign-up would not count towards sales targets and financial rewards."[[71]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Commonwealth_Bank#cite_note-71)

Headquarters
------------

[[edit](https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Commonwealth_Bank&action=edit&section=15 "Edit section: Headquarters")]

Commonwealth Bank has moved through many different offices, starting off in Melbourne (Collins Street), then moving to Martin Place in Sydney's CBD. In 2009, CBA moved into Darling Park Tower 1. During the Sydney Covid-19 lockdown in 2020-2022, CBA moved staff into their new offices, CBP North, and CPB South (Commonwealth Bank Place North and South), on Harbour Street, near Tumbalong Park. In October 2023, CBA occupied levels 14-21, and 27 of DP1 (Darling Park Tower 1). By the end of 2023, CBA moved the remaining staff from levels 14-21 out of DP1.

As of October 2024, all Commonwealth Bank staff members work out of CBP South, CBP North, The Foundry (Redfern, NSW), Axel (Redfern, NSW), or CBS (Commonwealth Bank Square), with the exception of the remaining staff in DP1.

Bank structure
--------------

[[edit](https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Commonwealth_Bank&action=edit&section=16 "Edit section: Bank structure")]

### Customer Service Network

[[edit](https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Commonwealth_Bank&action=edit&section=17 "Edit section: Customer Service Network")]

[![Image 12](https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/50/Commonwealth_Bank_branch_office.jpg/250px-Commonwealth_Bank_branch_office.jpg)](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/File:Commonwealth_Bank_branch_office.jpg)

A Commonwealth Bank branch office

This division delivers financial services to personal and small business customers. It provides bank accounts and credit products to consumers.

### Premium Business Services

[[edit](https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Commonwealth_Bank&action=edit&section=18 "Edit section: Premium Business Services")]

Premium Business Services was formally split into two departments in 2009, Institutional Banking & Markets (IB&M) and Business & Private Banking (B&PB). IB&M includes areas of the bank that provides services to Institutional Clients and Global Markets. B&PB includes areas of the bank that provides services to Business customers and private banking customers.

### Wealth Management

[[edit](https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Commonwealth_Bank&action=edit&section=19 "Edit section: Wealth Management")]

Wealth Management brings together the Groups funds management platform, master funds, superannuation, insurance and financial advice business support. [Colonial First State](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Colonial_First_State "Colonial First State"), Colonial First State Global Asset Management and CommInsure all form part of Wealth Management. CBA has been granted a [MySuper](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/MySuper "MySuper") authority, enabling it to continue to receive default superannuation contribution from 1 January 2014.

International operations
------------------------

[[edit](https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Commonwealth_Bank&action=edit&section=23 "Edit section: International operations")]

The Commonwealth Bank's international presence includes:

*   Retail [banks in New Zealand](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Banks_in_New_Zealand "Banks in New Zealand") ([ASB Bank](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/ASB_Bank "ASB Bank")), [Turkey](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Turkey "Turkey") (CommBiz) and Indonesia (99% of PT Bank Commonwealth)
*   Banking investments in China (20 per cent in both Qilu Bank and [Bank of Hangzhou](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bank_of_Hangzhou "Bank of Hangzhou")) and Vietnam, (20 per cent stake in Vietnam International Bank)
*   County banks in Hebei and Henen Provinces of China (15 branches and 8 sub-branches)
*   Commonwealth Bank branches in [London](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/London "London"), [New York City](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/New_York_City "New York City"), [Tokyo](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Tokyo "Tokyo"), [Hong Kong](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hong_Kong "Hong Kong"), [Shanghai](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Shanghai "Shanghai"), [Beijing](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Beijing "Beijing"), [Singapore](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Singapore "Singapore"), [Auckland](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Auckland "Auckland"), [Turkey](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Turkey "Turkey") and [Mumbai](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mumbai "Mumbai")
*   Joint venture life insurance businesses in Indonesia (PT Commonwealth Life) and China (37.5% stake in BoCommLife)
*   First State funds management business in the United Kingdom, Germany, France, Hong Kong, Singapore, Indonesia, Japan, United States and Dubai
*   Representative office in [Hanoi](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hanoi "Hanoi")
*   A Global Capability Center in [Bangalore](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bangalore "Bangalore"), [India](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/India "India")

Products and services
---------------------

[[edit](https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Commonwealth_Bank&action=edit&section=24 "Edit section: Products and services")]

The Commonwealth Bank is Australia's largest retail bank and offers customers a range of products and services, including loans, credit cards, transaction and savings accounts. It has the largest branch and ATM network.[[106]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Commonwealth_Bank#cite_note-106) It also offers services to people planning to move to Australia.[[107]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Commonwealth_Bank#cite_note-107)

### NetBank

[[edit](https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Commonwealth_Bank&action=edit&section=25 "Edit section: NetBank")]

The Commonwealth Bank offers online banking services through NetBank. NetBank allows customers to transfer funds, manage accounts, access assets and liabilities and also manage savings and saving goals.[[108]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Commonwealth_Bank#cite_note-Online_Banking-108) NetBank is also offered with a mobile app available for [iOS](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/IOS "IOS") and [Android](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Android_(operating_system) "Android (operating system)").[_[citation needed](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation\_needed "Wikipedia:Citation needed")_]

### Beem It

[[edit](https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Commonwealth_Bank&action=edit&section=26 "Edit section: Beem It")]

[Beem It](https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Beem_It&action=edit&redlink=1 "Beem It (page does not exist)") is an instant payment free-to-download mobile application owned by Commonwealth Bank, [NAB](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/National_Australia_Bank "National Australia Bank") and [Westpac](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Westpac "Westpac") later sold to Eftpos Australia. It offers an instant payment transfer service between registered users of the app regardless of which bank they are with. The app's main features include options to pay, transfer, request and split money.[[109]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Commonwealth_Bank#cite_note-109)

Sponsorship
-----------

[[edit](https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Commonwealth_Bank&action=edit&section=32 "Edit section: Sponsorship")]

Commonwealth Bank has been sponsoring [Cricket Australia](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cricket_Australia "Cricket Australia") for the women's game since the 1990s.[[110]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Commonwealth_Bank#cite_note-110)

In April 2021, Commonwealth Bank secured a four-year partnership deal with [Football Australia](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Football_Australia "Football Australia") for the naming rights of the women's national football teams as the Commonwealth Bank [Matildas](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Australia_women%27s_national_soccer_team "Australia women's national soccer team"), Commonwealth Bank [Young Matildas](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Australia_women%27s_national_under-20_soccer_team "Australia women's national under-20 soccer team"), and Commonwealth Bank [Junior Matildas](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Australia_women%27s_national_under-17_soccer_team "Australia women's national under-17 soccer team").[[111]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Commonwealth_Bank#cite_note-111)[[112]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Commonwealth_Bank#cite_note-112)

In November 2022, [FIFA](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/FIFA "FIFA") announced that Commonwealth Bank has signed on as an official supporter for the [2023 FIFA Women's World Cup](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2023_FIFA_Women%27s_World_Cup "2023 FIFA Women's World Cup").[[113]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Commonwealth_Bank#cite_note-113)[[114]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Commonwealth_Bank#cite_note-114)

[Institutional](https://www.commbank.com.au/institutional.html "Institutional") / Economic research & insights

![Image 5: Magnifying glass](https://www.commbank.com.au/content/dam/dynamic-media/business/institutional/2024-07/econ-research-insights_lghero.jpg)

Economic research & insights
============================

Our economic research and insights provides a comprehensive view on issues affecting the Australian and key international economies as well as financial markets and sustainability.

*   [Our data and analysis](https://www.commbank.com.au/institutional/economic-insight.html#data)
*   [The team](https://www.commbank.com.au/institutional/economic-insight.html#team)
*   [Economic insight to power decision making](https://www.commbank.com.au/institutional/economic-insight.html#decision)
*   [Featured content](https://www.commbank.com.au/institutional/economic-insight.html#featured)
*   [We can help](https://www.commbank.com.au/institutional/economic-insight.html#help)

 Our data and analysis 

Our data and analysis
---------------------

*   The Global Economic & Markets Research (GEMR) team provides clients with regular, real-time research and insights enriched by CommBank internally generated data, showing changes in the economy across income, savings, expenditure and lending.

To make it easier for clients to benefit from the award-winning reports produced by our team, we have unlocked access to all **[Economic Insights](https://www.commbankresearch.com.au/s/desks)**. **Economic Insights** no longer require a login or password and you will be able to view reports from our Chief Economist, access Australian and global economic perspectives from our team of experts and read our work on sustainability.

[Receive our economic insights direct to your inbox](https://www.commbankresearch.com.au/s/apply) 

 The team 

The Team
--------

The Global Economic & Markets Research (GEMR) team provides exceptional research and insights.

The GEMR team have extensive knowledge and experience in their related fields, including domestic and international economics, foreign exchange, sustainable economics and commodities market.

[Meet the GEMR team](https://www.commbankresearch.com.au/s/authors)

 Economic insight to power decision making 

Economic insight to power decision making
-----------------------------------------

*   Our specialist Economics team provide up-to-date commentary on issues affecting the economy, industries and financial markets.

### Australian Economics & Commodities

Developments in the Australian economy, its outlook as well as policy and key commodity markets. 
*   ### International Economics

Major international economies impacting on Australia and our clients, including the US, UK, Europe, China, Japan and New Zealand. 
*   ### **Sustainable Economics**

Insights into circular economy, new energy, carbon markets, climate change, biodiversity, and corporate disclosure. 

 Featured content 

Featured content
----------------

We help inform our clients by combining the latest technology with our financial insights.

![Image 6:  ](https://assets.commbank.com.au/is/image/commbank/hsi-newsroom-ecoresearch?$W375_H200$&fit=crop)

### CommBank Household Spending Insights

A unique view on Australian household future spending through analysis of actual customer behaviour and intentions.

[Find out more](https://www.commbank.com.au/business/latest/spending-intentions.html?ei=cta_hsi)

![Image 7:  ](https://www.commbank.com.au/content/dam/commbank-assets/federal-budget/2022-03/microphone_standard.jpg)

### The GEMR team discuss the latest economic insights

*   [Listen on Podbean](https://cbaresearchpodcast.podbean.com/)
*   [Listen on Apple Podcasts](https://podcasts.apple.com/au/podcast/commbank-global-economic-markets-update-podcast/id1504021438)
*   [Listen on Spotify](https://open.spotify.com/show/2n9Fyih1TYCqTgtPIHqbab?si=n1P97URkRVixbSa6aTYQEg)

![Image 8:  ](https://www.commbank.com.au/content/dam/commbank-assets/institutional/2021-05/video_standard.jpg)

### Global Economic & Markets Research Videos

Keep on top with insights from our economic experts to help inform decisions about your business.

[Find out more](https://www.youtube.com/user/commbankbusiness)

 We can help 

We can help
-----------

*   [![Image 9: ](https://www.commbank.com.au/content/dam/commbank-assets/pictograms/email_pictograms.svg)### Email globalmarketsresearch@cba.com.au](mailto:globalmarketsresearch@cba.com.au "Email")
*   [![Image 10: ](https://www.commbank.com.au/content/dam/commbank-assets/pictograms/pictogramCallUs64.svg)### Call Our Relationship Managers are here to connect you with the research and insights you need.](tel:0291170377 "Call")
*   [![Image 11: ](https://www.commbank.com.au/content/dam/commbank-assets/pictograms/pictogram_multiple_documents.svg)### Visit our economic portal If you are a client of the Commonwealth Bank and would like complete access to our research and insights, please speak to your Relationship Manager or visit commbankresearch.com.au/s/apply](https://www.commbankresearch.com.au/s/apply "Visit our economic portal")

Things you should know
----------------------

*   As this advice has been prepared without considering your objectives, financial situation or needs, you should, before acting on this advice, consider its appropriateness to your circumstances. View our [Financial Services Guide](https://www.commbank.com.au/content/dam/commbank/business/pds/ADB2684.pdf) (PDF 59kb). Commonwealth Bank of Australia ABN 48 123 123 124. Commonwealth Bank of Australia Company Description
==================================================

Commonwealth Bank of Australia provides retail and commercial banking services in Australia, New Zealand, and internationally.

It operates through Retail Banking Services, Business Banking, Institutional Banking and Markets, and New Zealand segments.

The company offers savings accounts and term deposits, banking accounts, credit cards, personal and business loans, car and equipment finance, business overdraft, and international payment services; home loans; and home and content, car, health, life, income protection, pet, and travel insurance products.

It also provides business cards; and capital raising solutions, transaction banking services, and risk management products and services.

Commonwealth Bank of Australia was founded in 1911 and is based in Sydney, Australia.and home and content, car, health, life, income protection, pet, and travel insurance products.

In-Depth SWOT Analysis of Commonwealth Bank: Big Four Bank
==========================================================

In the previous article, we did an in-depth SWOT analysis on the [U.S Bank](https://iide.co/case-studies/swot-analysis-of-us-bank/). Today we are here with another detailed SWOT Analysis of the Commonwealth Bank, one of the most dominant banks in Australia.

Commonwealth Bank or CommBank of Australia is [the largest bank by assets](https://www.statista.com/statistics/434596/leading-banks-in-australia-assets/) and the [top-ranking](https://www.advratings.com/asia-pacific/australian-banks-market-cap) bank by market capitalization in Australia headquartered in Sydney. Commonwealth Bank is dominating the commercial and retail banking market of Australia with its businesses across New Zealand, Asia, the United States and the United Kingdom.

The bank has maintained its position amongst the Australian and New Zealand market with all its efforts in working on its marketing strategies. In this developing digital period, they have been adopting advanced marketing strategies which are essential for reaching out and making a great Digital presence. So if you want to know how to utilize digital marketing for your benefit – take a look at our [free masterclass on digital marketing](https://iide.co/meetups/)by the CEO and Founder of IIDE, Karan shah.

Thus, this makes us keen to know everything about how Commonwealth Bank works. Here in this blog, we have a comprehensive SWOT analysis of Commonwealth Bank. But first, let’s take a look and know more about how Commonwealth Bank works as a firm.

[![Image 5: Aditya Shastri - Trainer at IIDE](https://iide.co/_next/image/?url=https%3A%2F%2Fiide-media.blr1.cdn.digitaloceanspaces.com%2Fproduction%2F41d8ec5394aa9afc0880c6064246043f-0fec609ba14c31f594bcad1cbc131ada.png&w=96&q=75)](https://iide.co/author/aditya-shastri)

[Aditya Shastri](https://iide.co/author/aditya-shastri)
Lead Trainer & Business Development Head at IIDE

Updated on: Jun 30, 2025

**About Commonwealth Bank**
---------------------------

![Image 6: SWOT Analysis of Commonwealth Bank - Commonwealth Bank](https://iide-media.blr1.cdn.digitaloceanspaces.com/production/upload-1736879168739-dbe8d911784a883f030848e82d65b315.jpg)

Commonwealth Bank commonly known as CommBank is an Australian Multinational banking group headquartered in Sydney, Australia. The bank was founded in the year 1911 by the Australian government running under Andrew Fisher Labor, later became fully privatized in 1996. The bank used to be the central issuer of Australian banknotes from the Department of the Treasury after the central bank. The bank is among [the top 4 big banks in Australia](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Banking_in_Australia#:~:text=Unsourced%20material%20may%20be%20challenged%20and%20removed.&text=Banking%20in%20Australia%20is%20dominated,Group%2C%20and%20National%20Australia%20Bank.), and the largest banking group in New Zealand and the Pacific region.

Commonwealth Bank provides a variety of financial services including retail, business and institutional banking, funds management, superannuation, insurance, investment and broking services. Since 1991, the bank has been listed on the Australian Stock Exchange. In Australia, the bank serves about 6 million consumers at over 1,100+ branches. It has around 43,500 staff & serves about 9 million consumers worldwide.

**Quick Stats on Commonwealth Bank**| Founder | Andrew Fisher Labor Government |
| --- |
| Year Founded | 1991 |
| Origin | Australia |
| No. of Employees | 43,585 |
| Company Type | Public |
| Market Cap | A$ 177.00 Billion (2021) |
| Annual Revenue | A$ 30.16 Billion (2020) |
| Net Income/ Profit | A$ 9.63 Billion (2020) |

### **Products & Services by Commonwealth Bank**

Commonwealth Bank provides different services to keep its consumers satisfied. Commonwealth Bank is one of the topmost banking groups in the world. Below mentioned are some of the Commonwealth Bank products and services.

*   Personal and commercial banking
*   Wealth management
*   Investment services
*   Financial planning
*   Credit cards
*   Insurance
*   Mortgages

### **Competitors of Commonwealth Bank**

Commonwealth Bank brings a huge competition for itself, as it provides services in the whole world. Below mentioned are some of the competitors for Commonwealth Bank:

*   Westpac banking
*   BNZ bank
*   HSBC bank
*   [ANZ](https://iide.co/case-studies/swot-analysis-of-anz/)
*   The Royal Bank of Scotland
*   OCBC bank

Now that we have some idea of how Commonwealth Bank works, let’s focus on a detailed SWOT analysis of Commonwealth Bank.

**SWOT Analysis of Commonwealth Bank**
--------------------------------------

SWOT analysis of Commonwealth Bank is the study of strengths, weaknesses, opportunities, and threats of the company. This will help the company understand strong factors for their growth, weakness, and threats to rectify them for further growth.

To better understand the SWOT analysis of Commonwealth Bank, refer to the infographics below:

![Image 7: SWOT Analysis of Commonwealth Bank - SWOT Infographics of Commonwealth Bank](https://iide-media.blr1.cdn.digitaloceanspaces.com/production/upload-1736879169601-1423cac48cae536d4be8add857d380d9.png)

Below is a step-by-step detailed guide to help you with the SWOT analysis of Commonwealth Bank.

### **Strengths of Commonwealth Bank**

Certain abilities of an organization that are advantageous in capturing market share, attracting more customers, and maximizing profits can be called the strengths of that organization.

*   **Extensive Network**: The bank has more than 42,000 employees with a global presence of 34+ countries with a very wide range of services including retail banking, premium business and wealth management services.

![Image 8: SWOT Analysis of Commonwealth Bank - The CommBank App](https://iide-media.blr1.cdn.digitaloceanspaces.com/production/upload-1736879170289-1cbe600cd2f7c71b96fa078edde7833c.jpg)

**(The CommBank App, Source: CommBank)**

*   **Brand Reputation:** Commonwealth Bank has been in the business of banking for a large number of years. Also, with the variety of secure services, it provides such as [the go on CommBank app](https://www.commbank.com.au/digital-banking.html) which is backed with secured digital channels to provide its users to securely transact with Commonwealth Bank. These big steps made Commonwealth Bank established as a leader in the industry. This helps the corporation to gain a reputation and get recognized easily.

**Useful Tip:** The time is digital and you can build your business reputation online by learning and implementing the ways from an [online reputation management course](https://iide.co/email-marketing-course-online/) which is taught by digital marketing industry experts in a practical oriented form.

*   **Strong Digital Marketing Strategy:** With a very strong online presence on every social media site has built a strong customer relationship. Want to know how social media works as a strength for Commonwealth Bank? Then you must check out the [benefits of social media marketing](https://iide.co/blog/social-media-benefits-for-business/) to get the answer to your query.
*   **Best in its Country:** The Bank is at the top of the big four banks in Australia and which itself tells that the bank is the best in Australia and New Zealand in terms of commercial and retail banking.
*   **Goods Returns on Capital Expenditure**: Commonwealth Bank is relatively successful at executing net income of A$ 9.63 Billion from annual revenue of A$ 30.16 Billion.

### **Weakness of Commonwealth Bank**

Weakness is the area where Commonwealth Bank can improve upon by building strategies. Below mentioned are the weakness of Commonwealth Bank:

*   **Limited Success Across the Core Business:** Although Commonwealth Bank is one of the leading organizations in its industry it faces challenges in moving to other product segments with its present culture.
*   **Cash Flow Problems:** There is a lack of proper financial planning at Commonwealth Bank regarding cash flows, leading to certain circumstances where there isn’t enough cash flow as required leading to unnecessary unplanned borrowing.
*   **Need to Invest More in New Technologies:** According to the country’s scale of expansion and the geographical areas Commonwealth Bank needs to invest more money in technology to integrate the processes across the board. Currently, the investment in technology is not on par as per the vision of the company.
*   **Environmental Criticism:** Commonwealth Bank has been criticized several times by environmental activists for financing oil sands extractions that cause negative effects on the environment and human health.
*   **Dependent on Australia & NZ:** Commonwealth Bank’s global presence is not up to the mark. The bank is dependent more on Australia & NZ. Also, the Commonwealth Bank is now competing with other Australian banks in terms of several branches.

### **Opportunities for Commonwealth Bank**

Opportunities are external factors that allow an organisation to grow and be more profitable. Following are some opportunities for Commonwealth Bank:

*   **Expansion to Other Global Markets:**The company is planning to expand to more developing countries. This serves them as an opportunity to acquire a new customer base.
*   **Development of Technology:** Since the FinTech industry is growing at a very rapid pace, there are advancements in technologies too. Using these kinds of technologies can increase efficiency and decrease cost.
*   **Increasing Income:**There has been an increase in average household income along with an increase in consumer spending following the recession. This will result in growth in the Commonwealth Bank’s target market with new customers that can be attracted towards the business.
*   **Population:** The population has been growing and is expected to grow at a positive rate for the upcoming years. This is beneficial for the Commonwealth Bank as there will be an increase in the number of potential customers that it can target.
*   **Interest Rate:** Lower interest rates than compared to previous years provides an opportunity for the Commonwealth Bank to undergo expansion projects that are financed with loans at a cheaper interest rate.
*   **Low Inflation Rate:** The low inflation rate can bring more stability in the market and enable credit at a lower interest rate to the customers of the Commonwealth Bank.

### **Threats to Commonwealth Bank**

The threats faced by the Commonwealth Bank are listed below:

*   **Currency Fluctuations:**As the company is operating in numerous countries it is exposed to currency fluctuations especially given the volatile political climate in several markets across the world.
*   **Competitor Technical Advancements:** New technological advancements by a few competitors within the sector constitutes a threat to Commonwealth Bank since customers who are drawn to this new technology may switch to competitors, reducing Commonwealth Bank’s overall market share.
*   **Pandemic:**Financial losses incurred by companies as well as individuals can cause a threat to the bank in repayment of loans.
*   **Increased Marketing Efforts:** Due to the rise of digital marketing, there is an increasing number of promotional messages which are being sent by competitors. It clutters up the space, which leads to losing out on customers. Commonwealth Bank is well versed and trying to adopt a [variety of latest digital marketing skills](https://iide.co/online-digital-marketing-certification/) to get ahead of the competition. You must also check out these skills to achieve the same.
*   **Controversies & Allegations:** Commonwealth Bank has been in more than 10+ controversies including the 2008 financial planning scandal, money laundering scandal, Bank bill swap rate allegations and many more. Recently, Commonwealth Bank has been sued by an Indonesian family for launching fake money laundering scams.

This ends our in-depth SWOT analysis of Commonwealth Bank. Let us conclude our learning below.

![Image 9: IIDE's Free Digital Marketing Masterclass Banner](https://iide.co/_next/image/?url=https%3A%2F%2Fiide-media.blr1.cdn.digitaloceanspaces.com%2Fproduction%2Fks-cta-bg-c9e946f530af069b43942e99a13c6126.webp&w=3840&q=75)

![Image 10: IIDE's Free Digital Marketing Masterclass Banner](https://iide.co/_next/image/?url=https%3A%2F%2Fiide-media.blr1.cdn.digitaloceanspaces.com%2Fproduction%2Fks-cta-bg-c9e946f530af069b43942e99a13c6126.webp&w=3840&q=75)

Learn Digital Marketing for FREE

*    45 Mins Masterclass 
*    Watch Anytime, Anywhere 
*    1,00,000+ Students Enrolled 

Register Now

![Image 11: Karan Shah - Founder & CEO at IIDE](https://iide.co/_next/image/?url=https%3A%2F%2Fiide-media.blr1.cdn.digitaloceanspaces.com%2Fproduction%2Fkaran-shah-cta-d95b96cf600b9f1bea3fa3d11c712d43.webp&w=3840&q=75)

![Image 12: Karan Shah - Founder & CEO at IIDE](https://iide.co/_next/image/?url=https%3A%2F%2Fiide-media.blr1.cdn.digitaloceanspaces.com%2Fproduction%2Fdm-masterclass-sidebar-cta-04eb8e7ae5d0b9a46826b977c404c7c9.webp&w=3840&q=75)

**To Conclude**
---------------

Commonwealth Bank is growing in the sector of banking in Australia, New Zealand, as well as the global market too. As we had a look at the SWOT Analysis of Commonwealth Bank, there is a lot more to grow in many aspects.

With the emergence of the digital world, where almost every individual spends at least an hour of his/her time on phones, proper digital marketing, and online presence can be a great way to improve customer relations.

If you want to learn digital marketing or want to upskill yourself. Take a look at our [3 Months Advanced Digital Marketing course](https://iide.co/online-digital-marketing-course/) where you can learn everything about digital marketing in-depth just like this case study.

We hope this blog on the SWOT Analysis of Commonwealth Bank has given you a good insight into the company’s strengths, weaknesses, opportunities, and threats. You can also read our comprehensive study on the [SWOT Analysis of JP Morgan Chase](https://iide.co/case-studies/swot-analysis-of-jp-morgan-chase/?swcfpc=1).

If you enjoy in-depth company research just like the SWOT analysis of Commonwealth Bank, check out our [IIDE Knowledge portal](https://iide.co/case-studies/swot-analysis-of-suzuki/#:~:text=IIDE%20Knowledge%20portal.) for more fascinating case studies.

Thank you for taking the time to read this, and do share your thoughts on this case study of the SWOT analysis of Commonwealth Bank in the comments section below.

# **How data analytics can boost your business**

Building a culture where data is used to inform decisions about your business is the way forward in a digital world.

![](/content/dam/commbank-assets/pictograms/social/socialX20.svg)
![](/content/dam/commbank-assets/pictograms/social/socialFacebook20.svg)
![](/content/dam/commbank-assets/pictograms/social/socialLinkedin20.svg)
![](/content/dam/commbank-assets/pictograms/social/Email_Icon.svg)

Many companies have been forced to rethink how they run their business this year. How that thinking is done and what resources are called on to make subsequent decisions is a key determinant of success.

## Related articles

![ ](/content/dam/commbank-assets/business/ecommerce/choosing%20ecommerce%20platform_artthumb.jpg)
![ ](/content/dam/commbank-assets/articles/2020-06/woman-giftbox_artthumb.jpg)

In an increasingly digital business world the most prevalent, informative and powerful resource is data. Most businesses generate more data than they could possibly use. Learning what data is available, what can be generated and what questions to ask of it is the key to more informed and effective business decisions.

This is called building data literacy – the critical ability to derive meaningful insights from data and apply it in a way that benefits your organisation.[1](#disclaimer)Increasing data literacy across an organisation, and in its leaders in particular, will help accelerate an organisation’s path to more effective business decisions.

### **Getting the most from the data**

Professional services firm Deloitte says it’s important to have the right analytics tools and technologies in place when an organisation engages more with its data. “Invest in tools that fit now and that will be flexible and powerful enough to grow with the organisation,” it says in its report *Building you data analytics capabilities.[2](#disclaimer)*

The next step is to ask smart questions that will provide actionable insights.

Those questions will be guided by the business’ strategy and could look like ‘What are our customers telling us? How do we measure up against our goals and against the competition? Where are costs exceeding return? Does that proposed new market or product meet our demographic and revenue criteria?

Customer-generated data can provide invaluable insights for any business, says Kate Morris, founder of Adore Beauty, a pioneer in retailing beauty products online in Australia.

She says digital businesses have access to many data points that provide valuable information about the customer.  “In most cases you’ll have more data than you could ever hope to use. There’s almost always data points that are easy to isolate. The key is to pick the pain points that are affecting the highest number of customers,” Morris says.

Data can identify why and how a customer uses an app and where on their journey they most commonly get stuck. Do they want different products, different delivery options or a smoother payment process? Using this data allows a company to position its products more appropriately, and helps retain and attract customers.

**Growth opportunities**

Euromonitor is an independent strategic market research group that has analysed the process of using data to make business decisions. In its report *8 Ways to Identify Market Opportunities for Business Growth[3](#disclaimer)* it discusses ways to take an even deeper dive into customer analytics and the market in which a business operates.

If a business is looking to invest or grow, it says customer segmentation can identify market opportunities. For instance, does the proposed location and market reach the target demographic?

Market and competitors’ data can help determine which brands and products are growing in a given industry and why. Businesses can then ask ‘How is our company placed? Do we have a competitive advantage? Is there an acquisition opportunity?’

Data can also be used to analyse complementary products or services that can boost revenue or increase product and service offerings. Euromonitor [cites](https://blog.euromonitor.com/8-ways-identify-market-opportunities-business-growth/) the example of a packaging company: by identifying and monitoring the sales of products it doesn’t currently package the company can determine if there’s an opportunity for it to package those products, particularly if their sales are rising.

**What’s happening in your business?**

Having a comprehensive understanding of your company’s financial position makes decision-making more effective. This goes for the board of an ASX-listed company or a small family-run business.

A tool such as CommBank’s Daily IQ can be used by businesses to give them timely insights about their business, based on transaction data.

Daily IQ offers a suite of tools, each displaying a dashboard of easy-to-read data that allows businesses and organisations to see trends and changes over time, identify opportunities and validate actions the business takes.

The Cash Flow tool is the most frequently used by businesses. It helps business better understand their cash position and provides year-on-year comparisons, enabling them to optimise their cash flow.

The Busiest Times tool provides a heat map illustration showing the busiest times of the day based on sales, helping to inform things like rostering and stock.

Using data derived from card transactions Daily IQ also provides insights on customer demographics, location and spending patterns which can help businesses better target their marketing or identify potential new business locations.

[Daily IQ](/business/online-banking/commbiz/daily-iq.html) is available for free to qualifying CommBank customers. You’ll find more information here.

**Things you should know**

**Things you should know**

### Commonwealth Bank of Australia General Information

#### Description

Commonwealth Bank of Australia is a commercial bank that provides services including retail, premium, business, and institutional banking, funds management, superannuation, insurance, investment, and share-broking products and services in Australia, New Zealand, and internationally. The bank provides retail banking services, including home loans, credit cards, personal loans, transaction accounts, and demand and term deposits. Commonwealth Bank also offers commercial products, such as business loans, equipment and trade finance, and rural and agribusiness products to corporations, government entities, and other institutions.
