========================

### Digital Distinction

CommBank’s latest Consumer Insights Report shows how businesses can enhance customer experiences as the rising cost of living brings on new spending, saving, and shopping behaviours.

[View report](https://www.commbank.com.au/content/dam/commbank-assets/business/industries/2023-09/consumer-insights-report-2023.pdf)[View executive summary](https://www.commbank.com.au/content/dam/commbank-assets/business/industries/2023-09/commbank-consumer-insights-report-executive-summary.pdf)

Finding and keeping value-driven consumers
------------------------------------------

*   [**Media release**](https://www.commbank.com.au/articles/newsroom/2023/09/consumer-insights-2023.html)
*   [**Regional snapshot**](https://www.commbank.com.au/content/dam/commbank-assets/business/industries/2023-09/consumer-insights-regional-snapshot-2023.pdf)
*   [**Retail snapshot**](https://www.commbank.com.au/content/dam/commbank-assets/business/industries/2023-09/consumer-insights-retail-snapshot-2023.pdf)
*   [**Hospitality snapshot**](https://www.commbank.com.au/content/dam/commbank-assets/business/industries/2023-09/consumer-insights-hospitality-snapshot-2023.pdf)

### What’s in the report

The Consumer Insights Report is based on the views of 5,279 Australians, exploring their changing attitudes and preferences when engaging with consumer-facing businesses.

We pinpoint what consumers now expect and value most about both their retail and hospitality experiences.

### Insights from your customers

Views expressed directly by existing and potential customers can help retail and hospitality businesses respond to changing expectations. In this report, we examine:

*   The impact of cost of living pressures on consumers’ spending and lifestyle choices.
*   What consumers believe supports a good customer journey, from discovery to checkout.
*   Uplifting digital experiences and technology adoption to attract customers and drive loyalty.
*   Benchmarking consumer preferences across retail and hospitality segments.

Key insights
------------

### Broad response to higher cost of living

*   90% of Australians are adopting deal-seeking behaviours and reviewing their spending choices.
*   73% are using promotional codes, cashback offers and rewards.
*   66% are doing more research before buying.
*   47% only buy from known and trusted brands.

### A seamless and flexible retail experience

*   85% want retailers to offer tech-enhanced processes and personalisation.
*   64% say data security and control are a must-have to purchase.
*   84% say a range of payment options for faster checkout is a must-have or nice to have.

### Bridging physical and digital in hospitality

*   80% want hospitality venues to offer tech-enhanced processes and personalisation.
*   2 in 3 say the in-venue experience or supportive staff are a must-have to book or order.
*   77% say payment options to split bills, tip and get digital receipts are a must-have or nice to have.

Expert commentary
-----------------

Jana Bowden, Professor of Marketing and Consumer Behaviour, Macquarie University

[Read expert view](https://www.commbank.com.au/articles/business/case-study-expert-view-jana-bowden-marketing-macquarie-university.html)

![Image 6:  ](https://assets.commbank.com.au/is/image/commbank/2019-10-08-Cristiana-Fiorini-26?$W728_H432$&fit=crop&scl=6)

Previous reports
----------------

![Image 9:  ](https://assets.commbank.com.au/is/image/commbank/A-273385943?$W780_H416$&fit=crop&align=%200,1)

### Consumer Insights Report: Circular Economy

This edition of CommBank’s Consumer Insights report explores the benefits for consumers and businesses of advancing Australia’s transition to a circular economy. The underlying research reveals the opportunity for businesses to reduce consumption and waste in society, positively influence consumer behaviour and drive circular economic growth.

[Read the report (PDF)](https://www.commbank.com.au/content/dam/commbank-assets/business/industries/2022-10/commbank-consumer-insights-report-10-2022.pdf)

![Image 10:  ](https://www.commbank.com.au/content/dam/commbank-assets/business/industries/2022-03/consumer-insights-social-purpose-report_standard.jpg)

### Consumer Insights Report: Social Purpose

This edition of CommBank’s Consumer Insights report puts the spotlight on social purpose. It explores shoppers’ attitudes towards businesses seeking to positively impact the world at large.

[Read the report (PDF)](https://www.commbank.com.au/content/dam/commbank-assets/business/insights/docs/consumer-insights-social-purpose-report.pdf)

![Image 11:  ](https://www.commbank.com.au/content/dam/commbank-assets/articles/2021-05/Consumer%20Insights%20Report_Tile_780x416.jpg)

### Consumer Insights Report: How the pandemic reshaped consumers

Consumers have encountered significant disruptions to the way they live, work and shop. Understanding the impact of the pandemic on their behaviours and attitudes, and whether these are permanent drivers, is critical for businesses in seeking to capture sales as economic recovery continues.

[Read the report (PDF)](https://www.commbank.com.au/content/dam/commbank-assets/business/industries/2021-05/Consumer%20Insights%20Report.pdf)

Get in touch with our industry specialists
------------------------------------------

[CommBank for Retailers](https://www.commbank.com.au/business/industries/retail.html?ei=specialised_retail) | [CommBank for Hospitality](https://www.commbank.com.au/business/industries/hospitality.html?ei=specialised_hospitality)

[Request a callback](https://www.commbank.com.au/content/commbank-neo/business/eform/industries?ei=cta_Callback_LP)

Things you should know
----------------------

*   **About CommBank Consumer Insights**

CommBank Consumer Insights is an exclusive, wide-ranging analysis of the Australian consumer. This edition focuses on understanding consumer attitudes, motivations and expectations of their experiences amid changes to the real and digital economy.

This edition is based on an online quantitative survey conducted by Fifth Quadrant on behalf of the Commonwealth Bank. The survey was conducted in May and June 2023 and was completed by 5,279 consumers of goods and services.

Each respondent answered questions relating to one category where they had spent money in recent months, including:

Groceries and liquor (n=406), clothing & footwear (n=406), homewares and household appliances (n=408), consumer electronics and entertainment including books, games, music and media (n=404), recreational sporting and outdoor goods (n=407), motor vehicle parts and accessories (n=406), health and beauty products (n=406), hardware, DIY, building and garden supplies (n=407), personal care services including hairdressing, beauty and weight loss treatments (n=406), fast food and quick service restaurants (n=405), pubs and clubs (n=408), restaurants and cafes (n=407), and accommodation including hotels, motels and AirBnb (n=403).

The sample was selected to ensure the results are nationally representative. All statistics and references to consumers in this report are based on the responses to the survey unless otherwise stated.

The report has been published for general information purposes only. As this information has been prepared without considering your objectives, financial situation or needs, you should, before acting on this information, consider its appropriateness to your circumstances, if necessary, seek professional advice. The Bank believes that the information in the report is correct and any opinions, conclusions or recommendations are reasonably held or made, based on the information available at the time of its compilation, but no representation or warranty, either expressed or implied, is made or provided as to accuracy, reliability or completeness of any statement made in the report. Any projections and forecasts are based on a number of assumptions and estimates and are subject to contingencies and uncertainties. Different assumptions and estimates could result in materially different results. All analysis and views of future market conditions are solely those of the Commonwealth Bank.

![Image 5:  ](https://www.commbank.com.au/content/dam/commbank-assets/about-us/2018-10/Gunyah_lghero.jpg)

Our history
===========

The Commonwealth Bank was founded under the Commonwealth Bank Act in 1911 and commenced operations in 1912, empowered to conduct both savings and general banking business. Today, we’ve grown to a business with more than 800,000 shareholders and 52,000 people working in the Commonwealth Bank Group. We offer a full range of financial services to help all Australians build and manage their finances.

*   [History](https://www.commbank.com.au/about-us/our-company/history.html#history)
*   [Amalgamations](https://www.commbank.com.au/about-us/our-company/history.html#amalgamations)
*   [Past leaders](https://www.commbank.com.au/about-us/our-company/history.html#leaders)
*   [Archives](https://www.commbank.com.au/about-us/our-company/history.html#archives)

 History 

Our history at a glance
-----------------------

*   [The beginnings through to development as a central bank 1911 - 1990](https://www.commbank.com.au/about-us/our-company/history/1912-1990.html)
*   [Commonwealth Bank during World War One](https://www.commbank.com.au/personal/newsroom/cba-in-world-war-one.html)
*   [The changing face of banking 1960 - 1991](https://www.commbank.com.au/about-us/our-company/history/1960-1991.html)
*   [Privatisation and subsequent developments 1991 onwards](https://www.commbank.com.au/about-us/our-company/history/1991-onwards.html)

### First Sydney branch

“Precisely at 10 o’clock yesterday morning, the doors of the Commonwealth Savings Bank in Moore Street were thrown open for business in the presence of a large number of spectators, including the Prime Minister Andrew Fisher.”

-_The Sydney Morning Herald_ Monday 13 January 1913

[Keep reading](https://www.commbank.com.au/guidance/newsroom/our-first-sydney-branch-201708.html)

![Image 6: Moore Street](https://www.commbank.com.au/content/dam/commbank-assets/about-us/2018-10/moore-st-sydney_50split_xl.jpg)

 Amalgamations 

Amalgamations
-------------

The Group has been involved in many mergers. Some pre-date the establishment of the Commonwealth Bank itself.

[Read more](https://www.commbank.com.au/about-us/our-company/history/amalgamations.html)

![Image 7: Huonville post office 1913](https://www.commbank.com.au/content/dam/commbank-assets/about-us/2018-10/Huon-1913_50split_l.jpg)

 Past leaders

------------

*   Governors, Managing Directors &Chief Executive Officers

 Archives 

Archives
--------

*   
### Commonwealth Bank of Australia Group Archives.

The Group Archives serves our internal needs and supplies information to the public about the organisation’s history and operations.

The Group Archives houses information about the Commonwealth Bank and other financial institutions whose archives have come to us as a result of[amalgamations](https://www.commbank.com.au/about-us/our-company/history/amalgamations.html) (including Colonial Mutual Limited and the Rural Bank of New South Wales).

Sources of information include:

    *   Annual reports and other publications (including brochures, posters and advertising materials)
    *   Records about the Commonwealth Bank’s current and former properties
    *   Records about our organisational structure and staffing
    *   Photographs of people, events and buildings
    *   Ledgers, registers and commercial records
    *   Memorabilia including currency, uniforms, furniture, safes, moneyboxes and gold scales
    *   An archive of employee magazines, corporate history files, terms and conditions, product disclosure statements and circulars
    *   Film, video, and other fragile audio-visual materials

The Archives also have an exhibition gallery, The Vault, located at our South Eveleigh, Sydney office.

To consult records held by the Group Archives or to arrange a visit to The Vault please contact the Group Archives by email at archives@cba.com.au

Commonwealth Bank of Australia Group Archives.

History
-------

Commonwealth Bank was founded under the Commonwealth Bank Act in 1911 and commenced operations in 1912, empowered to conduct both savings and general banking business.

Today, we’ve grown to a business that serves 15.9 million customers, employs 48,900 people and has more than 800,000 shareholders.

We offer a full range of financial services to help secure and enhance the financial wellbeing of Australia’s people, businesses and communities.

[Read more](https://www.commbank.com.au/about-us/our-company/history.html)

![Image 32: At the Gunyah](https://www.commbank.com.au/content/dam/commbank-assets/about-us/2018-04/at-the-gunyah-charity-stall_50split_l.jpg)

International locations
-----------------------

*   ### [Asia](https://www.commbank.com.au/about-us/our-company/international-branches/asia.html)

With branches across Asia, the Bank provides financial services to both Australian clients with interests in Asia, and clients in the region who have business interests in Australia.

[Find out more](https://www.commbank.com.au/about-us/our-company/international-branches/asia.html) 
*   ### [European Union](https://www.commbank.com.au/about-us/our-company/international-branches/european-union.html "Europe")

The Bank has a long history in Europe building partnerships to provide specialist investment, advisory and financial services to clients.

[Find out more](https://www.commbank.com.au/about-us/our-company/international-branches/european-union.html) 
*   ### [New Zealand](https://www.commbank.com.au/about-us/our-company/international-branches/new-zealand.html "New Zealand")

CommBank New Zealand has its own local banking licence and operates in the corporate and institutional market as a full branch.

[Find out more](https://www.commbank.com.au/about-us/our-company/international-branches/new-zealand.html) 
*   ### [North America](https://www.commbank.com.au/about-us/our-company/international-branches/north-america.html "North America")

Located in New York, the Bank provides a comprehensive range of financial services to Australian and New Zealand clients and North American companies with business connections in Australasia.

[Find out more](https://www.commbank.com.au/about-us/our-company/international-branches/north-america.html) 
*   ### [United Kingdom](https://www.commbank.com.au/about-us/our-company/international-branches/europe.html)

With a presence in Europe since 1913, the Commonwealth Bank has more than 180 staff across the region.

[Find out more](https://www.commbank.com.au/about-us/our-company/international-branches/europe.html)

![Image 1](https://miro.medium.com/v2/resize:fill:64:64/1*dmbNkD5D-u45r44go_cf0g.png)

Inside The Commonwealth Bank’s $620K+ / Month Paid Search & Social Growth Strategy
==================================================================================

[![Image 2: Nathaniel Cheung](https://miro.medium.com/v2/resize:fill:64:64/1*OckDrWcFiBMjZJhS8A9IHQ.jpeg)](https://medium.com/@nathanielcheung?source=post_page---byline--56124ba54b59---------------------------------------)

[Nathaniel Cheung](https://medium.com/@nathanielcheung?source=post_page---byline--56124ba54b59---------------------------------------)

Follow

7 min read

·

Dec 8, 2019

[](https://medium.com/m/signin?actionUrl=https%3A%2F%2Fmedium.com%2F_%2Fvote%2Fp%2F56124ba54b59&operation=register&redirect=https%3A%2F%2Fmedium.com%2F%40nathanielcheung%2Finside-the-commonwealth-banks-620k-month-paid-search-social-growth-strategy-56124ba54b59&user=Nathaniel+Cheung&userId=277fbb059ca5&source=---header_actions--56124ba54b59---------------------clap_footer------------------)

[](https://medium.com/m/signin?actionUrl=https%3A%2F%2Fmedium.com%2F_%2Fbookmark%2Fp%2F56124ba54b59&operation=register&redirect=https%3A%2F%2Fmedium.com%2F%40nathanielcheung%2Finside-the-commonwealth-banks-620k-month-paid-search-social-growth-strategy-56124ba54b59&source=---header_actions--56124ba54b59---------------------bookmark_footer------------------)

[Listen](https://medium.com/m/signin?actionUrl=https%3A%2F%2Fmedium.com%2Fplans%3Fdimension%3Dpost_audio_button%26postId%3D56124ba54b59&operation=register&redirect=https%3A%2F%2Fmedium.com%2F%40nathanielcheung%2Finside-the-commonwealth-banks-620k-month-paid-search-social-growth-strategy-56124ba54b59&source=---header_actions--56124ba54b59---------------------post_audio_button------------------)

Share

![Image 3](https://miro.medium.com/v2/resize:fit:700/1*xWHgCB-UWQGGnISOP99wxw.png)

If you’re a digital marketing professional in Australia, you’ll have heard of the Commonwealth Bank.

They’re Australia’s largest bank and one of the country’s most recognisable brands.

They’re also a leader in digital banking and digital marketing. In 2019, they announced a $5 billion investment in technology to further its digital leadership and recorded a spend of $465 million on their marketing, advertising and loyalty operations.

Combine all this with the fact that they operate in one of the most competitive and regulated industries — the Commonwealth Bank make for an excellent example of how to market online successfully and sustainably.

In this following article, you’ll get to peek behind the Paid Search and Social strategies of the Commonwealth Bank and see how they acquire customers and build their brand through these popular digital channels.

**A Snapshot Of The Commonwealth Banks Website Traffic**
========================================================

The Commonwealth Bank’s website ranks #22 in Australia by traffic, with over 25 million visits a month.

![Image 4](https://miro.medium.com/v2/resize:fit:596/0*QlZDw7fhQIE_bI_D)

![Image 5](https://miro.medium.com/v2/resize:fit:590/0*HUU4V7MfXcfaoKlm)

In comparison, Westpac, another one of the ‘Big Four’ banks, ranks #33 in Australia with just shy of 15 million visitors a month.

![Image 6](https://miro.medium.com/v2/resize:fit:594/0*old4CS7QpCv-BXyo)

The majority of the Commonwealth Bank’s traffic (80%) comes from mobile devices.

![Image 7](https://miro.medium.com/v2/resize:fit:416/0*DPFruvObcP1HjKsp)

According to SEMRush, search traffic makes up 21% of the Commonwealth Bank’s traffic while social makes up 1.3%. (Paid Social is sometimes not included in this, so the actual amount of traffic from Social, both organic and paid, could be much higher).

![Image 8](https://miro.medium.com/v2/resize:fit:484/0*QJfiZD2VvaHbl28-)

**Paid Search Analysis**
========================

Search makes up a significant proportion of the Commonwealth Bank’s website traffic. As such Paid Search is something which they invest heavily in.

According to SEMRush, the Commonwealth spends an estimated $620K a month on Paid Search alone:

![Image 9](https://miro.medium.com/v2/resize:fit:700/0*aoumSwt6LHUpXvJa)

As you can see, this spend has ramped up significantly in 2019 after a subdued start to the year because of the Banking Royal Commission.

Searches and advertising for home loans — one of the Commonwealth Bank’s most significant sources of business and search traffic — also traditionally picks up during Springtime.

![Image 10](https://miro.medium.com/v2/resize:fit:700/0*EmSoajESvRsSKRhV)

The Commonwealth Bank leads the ‘Big Four’ banks when it comes to their spend and volume of paid search traffic, confirming their reputation for being a leader in the digital space.

![Image 11](https://miro.medium.com/v2/resize:fit:691/0*QD1ERXwT3NgwnNtD)

Paid keywords which bring in the most traffic, and which the bank spends the most money on, are for mortgages, car loans and personal loans.

![Image 12](https://miro.medium.com/v2/resize:fit:389/0*MevtSQnJ74I9kv39)

Interestingly, the top three paid keywords are for calculators.

Online calculators tend to be a popular search and lead generation tool in the finance space. They are highly interactive (unlike articles) and gather valuable data which can be used to screen and pre-qualify prospects.

Here’s one of the Commonwealth Bank’s Google Search ads and landing pages for their top search keyword, ‘mortgage repayment calculator’:

![Image 13](https://miro.medium.com/v2/resize:fit:501/0*kkM1VlOTz5Q143q6)

![Image 14](https://miro.medium.com/v2/resize:fit:350/0*lUefp0NI5oNlhpPA)

One great addition to this landing page is the property search, which leverages data from third-party provider, Domain.

People can search and see what they could get with what they could borrow. And of course, there are smart placements for the Commonwealth Bank’s mortgage services.

![Image 15](https://miro.medium.com/v2/resize:fit:408/0*RNK807nwCnxi24Uj)

**Other Observations About The Commonwealth Bank’s Paid Search Ads**

**>Many ads link to a different URL and landing page to their organic search result partner.** This allows landing page variations for paid search ads to be tested and optimised. And also allows the design to be tailored for paid traffic (e.g. removing the menu in the header, removing links to content, etc.)

**>Tracking parameters:** I found two URL parameters when clicking through on the Commonwealth Bank’s Google Search Ads.

One with 3 parameters: _?_**_pid_**_=133484&_**_sc\_psk_**_=62908&_**_sc\_crkey_**_=381762352493&m_

The other format I found included the above plus the usual UTM parameters (source, medium, campaign), internal campaign id, search keyword, match type and device (c=desktop, m=mobile as per Google’s ValueTrack nomenclature):

_?_**_cid_**_=cr:hl:BAU\_1909&_**_utm\_source_**_=sem&_**_utm\_medium_**_=goog&_**_utm\_campaign_**_=BAU\_1909&_**_keyword_**_=home%20loan%20repayment%20calculator&_**_matchtype_**_=e&_**_pid_**_=132966&_**_sc\_psk_**_=353030&_**_sc\_crkey_**_=382846488158&_**_c_**

I’m not 100% clear why there’s an inconsistency but they probably have reasoning for doing so (if you are spending the amount they are on ads, religious tracking is important to allow you to know what and how to optimise).

**Paid Social Analysis**
========================

It’s unclear how much the Commonwealth spends on Paid Social channels like Facebook & Instagram — two of the most popular platforms.

However, with Facebook being the second largest advertising network after Google, you can bet they are investing serious money on there.

When we take a look at the Commonwealth Bank’s Ad Library on Facebook, which shows what ads they are running on Facebook and Instagram, we see there are a few different types of ads.

First, there’s ads which advertise a specific offer:

![Image 16](https://miro.medium.com/v2/resize:fit:520/0*n94gRwRNHfF00C9c)

![Image 17](https://miro.medium.com/v2/resize:fit:520/0*neo3ZKNw9SdPtF-r)

![Image 18](https://miro.medium.com/v2/resize:fit:521/0*m54MZqu9-LKjn8c6)

There’s also ads for their charitable initiatives:

![Image 19](https://miro.medium.com/v2/resize:fit:521/0*u6R_7pDjyE1Hshrm)

They also run their TV ads on paid social:

![Image 20](https://miro.medium.com/v2/resize:fit:521/0*Ac8UeclUqXnu7Xzt)

And they also promote content:

![Image 21](https://miro.medium.com/v2/resize:fit:521/0*lEeJQ8jMrSJH6W4l)

On the linked article, there is, of course, a call-to-action at the end to allow the performance of the content piece to be measured easily in terms of leads generated, not just engagement or clicks.

![Image 22](https://miro.medium.com/v2/resize:fit:598/0*tXZavyxaVX4Dc1h_)

Curiously, ads for more news-driven content could not be found. If we look at the CBA Newsroom, we see lots of great articles which could be adapted into Paid Social Campaigns.

For example, this article on unclaimed benefits would make for an attention-grabbing advertisement for the Commbank app.

![Image 23](https://miro.medium.com/v2/resize:fit:530/0*z44n0XF58E9fmzyc)

While this media release on home buying intentions could be adapted for an ad targeting home buyers and sellers (who want to know what the market is like currently), and offers to find out how much they could borrow, linked within the article.

![Image 24](https://miro.medium.com/v2/resize:fit:520/0*_qy4VU5BAyN0T5DS)

These Advertorial-style Paid Social ads would likely perform well for the Commonwealth Bank, and with such a cutting-edge digital team, I would not be surprised if they start (or already have) tested them.

**Other Observations About The Commonwealth Bank’s Paid Social Ads**

*   **All ads in their Facebook Ad Library (which covers both Facebook & Instagram) use video, with none using static images.** This could be because they have found the videos to offer lower CPMs and CPCs.
*   **Only one ad variation for each campaign (with the exception of one campaign) could be found.** This was surprising as you’d expect multiple ad variations to be running. Though they may have already done rounds of testing and found the winners previously.
*   **Fewer products and services promoted compared to Paid Search.** This could be due to the fact that their focus or capabilities are more developed in Paid Search. Or that they have a found a better return on investment on Paid Search than Paid Social. Or that they have found it better to focus on more select campaigns for Paid Social.

Summary
=======

The Commonwealth Bank is a leader in digital and digital marketing. They spend millions every year on Paid Search and Social, generate enormous amounts of traffic and revenue from it, and operate in one of the most competitive and regulated industries.

As such, they provide an excellent example of how to leverage these popular online advertising channels profitably and sustainably.

[About us](https://www.commbank.com.au/about-us.html "About us") / [Our company](https://www.commbank.com.au/about-us/our-company.html "Our company") / [History](https://www.commbank.com.au/about-us/our-company/history.html "History") / 1960 - 1991

![Image 5:  ](https://www.commbank.com.au/content/dam/commbank-assets/about-us/2018-10/moneybox_lghero.jpg)

1960 - 1991
===========

The changing face of banking. 

*   [Developments](https://www.commbank.com.au/about-us/our-company/history/1960-1991.html#developments)
*   [Diversification](https://www.commbank.com.au/about-us/our-company/history/1960-1991.html#diversification)
*   [Computerisation](https://www.commbank.com.au/about-us/our-company/history/1960-1991.html#computerisation)
*   [Overseas activities](https://www.commbank.com.au/about-us/our-company/history/1960-1991.html#overseas)
*   [Deregulation](https://www.commbank.com.au/about-us/our-company/history/1960-1991.html#deregulation)
*   [Mergers](https://www.commbank.com.au/about-us/our-company/history/1960-1991.html#sbv)

 Developments 

Developments
------------

Many significant banking developments occurred throughout the 1960s. The Commonwealth Bank celebrated its Golden Jubilee in 1962, Saturday morning trading ceased, employment of part-time staff began and improved career opportunities for women became available. Decimal currency, Christmas Club Accounts, personal loans and variations on traditional savings accounts were introduced.

![Image 6: Decimal currency 1966](https://www.commbank.com.au/content/dam/commbank-assets/about-us/2018-10/decimal-currency-1966_50split_l.jpg)

 Diversification 

Diversification
---------------

*   During the 1970s, our operations expanded into home insurance and travel (1974) and the following year, we formed our own finance company, Commonwealth Bank Finance Corporation Ltd (CBFC). During 1988, the Commonwealth Bank entered the managed investment and life insurance arena with the establishment of wholly owned subsidiaries Commonwealth Life Ltd and Commonwealth Management Services Ltd. 

 Computerisation 

Computerisation & changing face of banking
------------------------------------------

Mechanisation had gradually replaced traditional hand posting methods in use since the Commonwealth Bank’s foundation. In December 1969, we introduced the ‘Black Light’ Signature System, which recorded ‘invisible’ signatures in passbooks enabling withdrawals at branches other than the customer’s own without making prior arrangements.

Computers started to change the way internal processes, telling facilities and routine operations were conducted. Our online computer network was complete on 15 July 1985 when the Norfolk Island branch joined in. Plastic credit and debit cards began to be used as the basis for transactions, starting with the launch of Bankcard in 1974, then Keycard in 1981. The Commonwealth Bank affiliated with Visa International and Interbank Card Association (Master Charge) in 1979.

Automatic telling machines (ATMs) began with the launch of Autobank in 1981. EFTPOS (Electronic Funds Transfer at Point of Sale) commenced in 1984 and electronic home and office banking became available in 1985.

![Image 7: Computer centre 1971](https://www.commbank.com.au/content/dam/commbank-assets/about-us/2018-10/computer-centre-1971_50split_xl.jpg)

 Overseas activities 

Overseas activities & dealings
------------------------------

*   The island branch network was handed over to established local banking institutions – in Papua New Guinea (1974) and Solomon Islands (1981) – and important points of representation were opened in New York, Tokyo and Singapore. We widened our foreign exchange dealings and provision of services for customers engaged in business overseas and during February 1989, the Commonwealth Bank acquired a 75 per cent share in the New Zealand-based ASB Bank Ltd (expanded to 100 per cent in 2000). 

 Deregulation 

Deregulation of the banking industry
------------------------------------

*   Deregulation of the banking industry and the subsequent entry of foreign banks into Australia in the mid-1980s posed significant challenges. These were met initially with restructuring of the Commonwealth Bank's internal organisation. New products and services were developed, targeted to meet the requirements of groups outside our traditional customer base. This process culminated in the organisation’s conversion from a government-owned entity into a public company. 

 Mergers 

Merger with State Bank of Victoria
----------------------------------

*   On 26 August 1990, the Commonwealth Bank entered into an agreement with the Treasurer of Victoria for a merger with the State Bank of Victoria (SBV). The Commonwealth Bank became the successor in law to SBV on 1 January 1991, creating Australia's largest domestic bank and further strengthening the Commonwealth Bank's leadership in retail branch banking.

![Image 5:  ](https://assets.commbank.com.au/is/image/commbank/branch-ourpeople-cba?$W1956_H1216$&fit=constrain&cropN=0.,0.2,1,1)

Commonwealth Bank of Australia
==============================

*   [Who we are](https://www.commbank.com.au/about-us.html#who)
*   [Leadership and Governance](https://www.commbank.com.au/about-us.html#leadership)
*   [Investors](https://www.commbank.com.au/about-us.html#investors)
*   [Sustainability](https://www.commbank.com.au/about-us.html#sustainability)
*   [Newsroom](https://www.commbank.com.au/about-us.html#newsroom)
*   [Careers](https://www.commbank.com.au/about-us.html#careers)

Who we are
----------

We are guided by our purpose – building a brighter future for all.

Our strategy, to build tomorrow's bank today for our customers, reflects our commitment to use the strength of CBA to support our customers, invest in our communities and provide strength and stability for the broader economy.

We are one of the leading banks in Australia, serving more than 17 million customers. We focus on providing retail and commercial banking services predominantly in Australia, and in New Zealand through our subsidiary, ASB.

Our products and services are provided through our divisions, Retail Banking Services, Business Banking, Institutional Banking and Markets, and ASB New Zealand.

[Learn more about our history and international locations](https://www.commbank.com.au/about-us/our-company.html#history)

![Image 6: Asian family and friends sitting around a picnic table outside their country house enjoying time together and barbecuing.](https://assets.commbank.com.au/is/image/commbank/G-1320068799?$Responsive_Align_Center_Top$)

### Our customers

Our strategy to build tomorrow’s bank today for our customers is centred on improving customers’ experience and solving their unmet needs.

We aim to be the trusted financial partner in the lives of our customers. By creating strong relationships and prioritising our customers, we provide engaging and relevant customer experiences.

Our Board, people and suppliers come to work each day to build a brighter future for all. Our[Code of Conduct](https://www.commbank.com.au/content/dam/commbank-assets/about-us/docs/cba-code-of-conduct.pdf)guides our decision-making to ensure we provide better outcomes for our customers and reflect their expectations of us.

### Your Customer Advocate

The Customer Advocate and Community and Customer Advocacy team are here to make sure our customers are treated fairly. They work independently within CBA to improve our products, systems and processes.

[Find out more about the Customer Advocate](https://www.commbank.com.au/about-us/customer-commitment/customer-advocate.html)

Leadership and Corporate Governance
-----------------------------------

*   ### Board of Directors

The CBA Board comprises independent, skilled and diverse members, who ensure sound and prudent management of CommBank and the effective delivery of our purpose.

[Meet our Board](https://www.commbank.com.au/about-us/our-company.html#board) 
*   ### Executive Leadership Team

Our executive team ensures the business achieves profitable growth and supports and encourages employees.

[Meet our Team](https://www.commbank.com.au/about-us/our-company.html#exec) 
*   ### Corporate governance

Strong corporate governance ensures we maintain the highest professional standards and act with integrity in our operations.

[Learn more about CBA's corporate governance](https://www.commbank.com.au/about-us/shareholders/corporate-profile/corporate-governance.html) 

Investors
---------

Visit our Investor centre for information on our securities, financial results, announcements, sustainability reporting, and other disclosures.

[Find out more](https://www.commbank.com.au/about-us/investors.html?ei=investors)

![Image 7:  ](https://www.commbank.com.au/content/dam/commbank-assets/about-us/2018-04/commbank_office_1_singlecolumn.jpg)

Sustainability
--------------

### Sustainability at CBA
